knowledge: Malware, which is short for malicious software, can be a file or a piece of code, which is typically delivered over a network, that can infect, steal, explore or perform any behaviour an attacker wants. A malware compromised device may be used by an attacker to gain control of the device, steal sensitive information, explore other devices on the network, or infect other devices.

Social engineering is tricking a user using psychological manipulation to give away sensitive or personal information. Remember, humans, are very trusting and want to help out by default. Attackers can exploit that for example to obtain credentials to compromise Softwaregenix's asset which can lead to the deployment of ransomware or data breach. Both are very damaging to Softwaregenix.

Email phishing is when attackers impersonate a legitimate organization via email which is designed to steal information. The emails can convey a sense of urgency and is typically about password resets, account hack notifications, payment notifications, etc. Users are tricked to give away sensitive information on a fake website that can lead to account compromise, malware installation, data breaches, etc. Did you know that phishing is responsible for 90% of security breaches?

Spear phishing is when the attacker targets a specific individual or group of individuals rather than a generic user base via email. Emails are personalized with the recipient's name, company, phone number, etc. This technique usually takes time for the attacker to prepare as it requires gathering data from various sources.

Business email compromise (BEC) is a type of email scam where attackers impersonate a legitimate employee or business partner and make a seemingly legitimate request to disclose sensitive information or perform actions that benefit the attackers financially.

Ransomware, which is all the rage recently, 2022 as of writing this, is a type of malware that encrypts the whole system drive or user's personal files and folders with a key/password. In either case, access to the computer or user's files is restricted with some sort of ransom message. For large corporations, there is usually some contact information for ransom negotiation. Some ransom groups even have a 24/7 support channel! Once payment has been received, the key/password is provided and the assets can be decrypted.

Cybersecurity tries to protect Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability (CIA). Confidentiality is ensuring data is only available to the authorized person or process, Integrity is ensuring data can only be modified by an authorized person or process, Availability is ensuring data is accessible to authorized person or process. Compromising any of the triads is a security incident.

There are often blatantly obvious indicators of a phishing or spear-phishing email. 1. The address from which it was sent will be fake, for example, if the email is impersonating Netflix, it can be from john@gmail.com, or can have typos that are easy to miss, for example, NitFlix. Legit company correspondence will use their domain name. It may use the same logos as the company it's claiming to be from. 2. The email can have unprofessional greetings like, "Hi Dear", "Greetings", "Dear Sir/Madam" etc. Legit communication will likely address you by your name. 3. It may have several spelling mistakes in the subject and the body of the email. Needless to say, this will not be the case for legit communications. They know how to spell! 4. It will almost always include a link and invite you to click to solve the problem the email is addressing and request sensitive information. You will rarely be asked to share sensitive information over email by legit companies. If you hover over the link, it might be something unrecognizable. 5. It can have strange unexpected attachments. Legit companies will never send unsolicited attachments your way. Check out the 7 ways to recognize a phishing email in the reference section from which this blurb of information was based on.

The impact of a successful malware infiltration into a company network such as ours is at first, financial. This could be a direct loss of capital that the attackers might have stolen, or fines to various regulatory organizations, like GDPR, PIPEDA, HIPAA, etc. It could also be from compensating customers due to a data breach. The second impact is the loss of intellectual properties, which are sensitive business information. While it's possible to recover from a financial loss, it's difficult to recover from the loss of intellectual properties as this is what gives Softwaregenix a competitive edge over our competitors. The third impact is damage to company reputation. If our clients lose our trust, they will not be inclined to do business with us in the future. We might go out of business!

As per company policy, you should use your Softwaregenix email only for business communications. Please do not use it for personal reasons such as sign up for an Amazon account with it. Use your personal email instead for non-business needs. In addition, don't forget as per company policy, if you are sending sensitive information regarding your work, please encrypt it using AES, and send it as an attachment using your Softwaregenix email. Never use your personal email to send sensitive information.

As per company policy, you are prohibited to use your personal web-based email while on the Softwaregenix network. Please use your personal smart device instead for checking the next shipment of your Amazon order!

questions.question: You notice an email from macrosoft.com with the subject, "Your account was compromised." What kind of attack is this?
answers: Business Email Compromise (BEC).
Ransomware.
Email phishing.
questions.correct_answer_response: You got it! Be on the lookout for suspicious emails, text messages, etc.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: No that's not it. Read below.

questions.question: You notice you have an email titled, "Unusual GitHub activity detected". The email has just one blue link titled "Check recent activity". What do you do?
answers: No questions asked. You delete it pronto!
You click on the link. After all, what's the worst that can happen, right? Softwaregenix has a great firewall and antivirus solutions.
You check your Github account for any unusual activity recently.
questions.correct_answer_response: You got it! This is a very crude attempt at phishing. This was an easy one mind you!
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Uh oh! An empty email with just a blue link is a HUGE red flag. It's a very crude email phishing attempt. Just delete it!

questions.question: You get an urgent email from our IT asking for your password for an emergency, otherwise you will get locked out in the next 5 minutes. What do you do?
answers: You respond immediately with your password! It is from our IT after all, right?
You delete the email. You should never share your password for any circumstances!
You contact our IT and share your password verbally.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct! You should under no circumstances share your password with anyone, even our IT! It's a phishing attempt.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Nope. You should never ever share your password! Phishing emails are designed with a sense of false urgency. Please stop and think first.

questions.question: You get an email from your team lead with an attachment "unpack_me_codebase.exe". There are instructions in the body of the email to run it as soon as possible. What do you do?
answers: It's from your team lead!! You run it without hesitation. He couldn't have sent weird stuff your way.

You verify that the email was from your boss by checking the from address carefully, which appears correct. You then contact your boss and ask if he sent the email and inform him that his email account may have been compromised.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct! You should never open an executable file sent over email even if it's from your team lead. His email account may have been compromised.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Oops. You opened the link and boom, now you have malware installed in your workstation. It's spreading over the network! Never open executables attached in an email.

questions.question: You get an email from your team lead, who is currently participating in a conference in a far far away country. He is having difficulty connecting to GitHub and requesting you to upload a zipped copy of your current project's codebase to a secure website he provided. What do you do?
answers: Your team lead is having GitHub login difficulty so might as well upload the codebase zipped up. After all, the email address is your team lead's.
Hmm. Even though his email address is correctly typed, you suspect something is afoot. You decide to contact your team lead directly via his phone and ask him about the request.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct! This is an example of a Business Email Compromise attack. Your team lead's account may have been spoofed. An attacker has gained knowledge of your team lead's whereabouts and is trying to gain access to sensitive information.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Nope. This is an example of a Business Email Compromise attack. Your team lead's account has been spoofed. Try contacting him directly via some other means.

questions.question: You get an email from Github with a security code. It has a link that directs you to a website to enter the security code but you need to login first. How do you respond?
answers: Your security sense is tingling. You don't recall triggering a 2FA challenge. You haven't even turned on your 2FA. You delete the email.
It's from Github! You must have been logged out somewhere. You click on the link and login to your Github account and provide the security code.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct. This is a kind of phishing attack. You should really set up the 2FA on your GitHub account.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Sad face again. This is a kind of phishing attack. Check the link and ensure you have 2FA on your Github account.

questions.question: You work on a shared workstation and when you login, you notice your workstation is noticeably sluggish. When you open your browser, you notice unexpected pop-ups. What do you do?
answers: Well, business workstations are shared by many employees so perhaps the hard drive is full. You go about your day.
You shut down the workstation and call IT. You twiddle your thumb in the meantime.
You unplug your workstation from the network and call IT. You twiddle your thumb in the meantime.
questions.correct_answer_response: Yup. Your workstation may have been compromised. It could have been from the previous session with a different employee. Leaving the workstation isolated helps IT conduct digital forensic.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: The worst thing you can do when you suspect an infection is to shut down the workstation. You are erasing digital evidence from memory. IT could find it useful for forensic analysis.

questions.question: You are awesome at your work, getting good feedback, and have a great feeling of accomplishment. Yet you feel you are not able to grow as you would have liked. You receive a phone call from a tech company recruiter with a lucrative job offer. He is quite knowledgeable on tech and asks you some specific questions about your current project. How do you respond?
answers: It wouldn't hurt to share some details. The guy appears genuine so there is no harm in sharing. You may land your dream job!
Hmm. You recall that you have NDAs to honour and can't share project-specific details. You decline.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct. You might have been a victim of social engineering and the fellow was trying to get some work-related information from you. It may be used for planning further attacks.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Even though the dream job sounds really lucrative, this could have been literally anyone trying to get some insider information from you. This is an example of social engineering attack.

questions.question: You come in to work on Monday morning energized by an eventful weekend, turn your monitor on and is greeted with a message, "Your files are now encrypted. Pay us 50 bitcoins to unlock." What kind of attack is this?
answers: Ransomeware
Malware
Virus
Someone's idea of a cruel joke. Restarting the workstation will surely fix this.
questions.correct_answer_response: That's correct. It is a classic example of ransomware. You should contact your IT.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Nope. That's ransomware. Has all the classic signs in it. It is a special kind of malware.

questions.question: You have been given admin privileges and really need Adobe Photoshop to create a snazzy poster to impress your client and present your latest work. You don't have time for an IT request which can take days so you head off to a torrent site, download and install Photoshop. What could you have unleashed?
answers: Malware of any kind, like ransomware, key loggers, viruses, etc.
Torrent sites are perfectly safe and there is no risk of infection. They are vetted before being allowed on site.
Could be an example of phishing.
questions.correct_answer_response: Correct. Torrent sites can host all sorts of fun dangerous stuff along with legitimate software. Malware is often bundled with them.
questions.incorrect_answer_response: Nope. Attackers love to bundle various sorts of malware with legitimate cracked software, hoping to score a target. You may have just compromised the security of your company. Stick to legitimate IT requests. Remember, with great admin power comes great responsibilities.

welcome: Hiya! Welcome to a very simple email and malware awareness training and educational game. You can learn some cool stuff like our company policies, information about email phishing and malware, or if you feel confident, head straight to scenario-based multiple-choice questions trivia game. There is a scoring system but don't worry! Your boss won't be notified if you do poorly. Feel free to browse different sections. Have fun!
attack_vectors: Did you know the USB you are carrying might contain malware that can infect your station? It can wreak havoc by encrypting all computers in our network if it's ransomware.
Leave your station locked when you leave your desk temporarily. If you are done for the day, sign off. You are leaving your workstation open for intruders to compromise if you don't lock or sign off.
I know it's tempting to know what your colleagues on a different team are working on next room. Hold that temptation! You are bound by NDA just like they are.

Always check for phishing emails. Check for common indicators like sender's address, spelling errors, weird links. Should you click on it, you might be directed to a compromised website and be prompted to download and run a file, sometimes without even clicking! And there goes our security. Welcome ransomware!

You know you are awesome at work and many recruiters are trying to get to you. Do you know that some attackers may pose as recruiters with lucrative job offers and social engineer you to get confidential information about our company? Always verify the source!

If you notice that your workstation is running extra sluggish, and see some other strange indicators like strange popups, your workstation might have been compromised. Unplug your workstation from the network and call out IT.

Did you know that the average cost of a data breach according to a report by IBM Canada in 2021 was around $6.76 million per incident? All it takes is one weak link and the weakest link in the security business is your kind. That's correct, Homo Sapiens, aka YOU! Remember to be vigilant and exercise good security habits.
Did you know that Softwaregenix has policies, standards and guidelines for good security posture and YOU as an employee are responsible to maintain it? Visit the policy section today!

Have you implemented 2-factor authentication across various web services that you use for work? If your password has been compromised, for example, you re-used your password from a website that has recently been breached, attackers can get access to your sensitive work materials and could potentially compromise our network. Implement 2FA today!

company_regulations.policy: Users must exercise caution when opening email attachments. Malware like viruses, trojans, and key loggers can be easily delivered as an email attachment.
company_regulations.procedure: Don't open email attachments you don't expect. Never open email attachments from unknown sources. Don't click on email links unless you absolutely trust it. Copy paste the email link in a text editor and check if its malformed.

company_regulations.policy: Users are required to use corporate email for business purpose only.
company_regulations.procedure: Do not use corporate email for personal use.

company_regulations.policy: Users must send sensitive data encrypted over email.
company_regulations.procedure: Encrypt sensitive email and attachments using AES in Microsoft Outlook.
company_regulations.guidelines: Sensitive data must never leave company network in plaintext. Email is an unsecure medium of transmission and company retains no control once email is sent. Exercise caution when dealing with sensitive data.

company_regulations.policy: Users must not use personal web-based email over company network.
company_regulations.procedure: Use your personal device to access your personal emails.

company_regulations.policy: Users must not use portable devices on company assets.
company_regulations.procedure: Don't connect USBs, your smart phones, media devices, etc. to any company workstation or servers.
